captions.text: Good morning Hank, it's Tuesday.

So next month I'm going on a brief tour with
Nat Wolff, Shailene Woodley, and Ansel Elgort,

who play, respectively, Isaac, Hazel, and
Gus in The Fault in Our Stars movie. And people

get to decide where we're going, and I have
to remember to talk about that, but first

I wanna talk about prisons. Boy, today's video
is gonna be funny!

Hank, a lot of times when we talk to non-profits
about outreach, they're like we're gonna make

a GIF ("guy-f") of poop on a stick because
clean water is important, and poop is funny,

and your audience will like that, because
you guys are funny. Then I'm like a) I think

you mean GIF ("jif") or GIF ("gif"), I mean
words belong to their users, but GIF ("guy-f")

is a stretch, and b) I don't think that funny
stuff actually works; people just want you

to talk about what you care about. It's not
like we rely on pratfalls to get laughs or
whatever.

Anyway, I've lost the thread. I really liked
your video about prisons but there were a

couple things...oooohhhh! Ow. Oh. That actually
turned into a very painful pratfall. That
better have been funny.

Right, anyway, I really liked your video about
prisons. It spurred some interesting discussions,

and I wanted to add a couple things. First,
there was a lot of talk in comments about

the role of race in sentencing, and the data
there is pretty overwhelming in the U.S. A

2013 study by the U.S. Sentencing Commission
found that African-Americans on average received

sentences 20% longer than white people who
committed similar crimes. Also, they found

that that disparity is actually increasing.
Socio-economic class is also a big factor

in sentencing, and the question of length
of sentence brings me to one other point I
want to make.

Per capita, a bunch of European countries
actually admit more people to prison per year

than the US does, but their sentences are
much shorter; and that's one of the big reasons

we have the highest incarceration rate in
the world. It isn't that we sentence so many

people to prison, it's that we sentence them
for so long. And in the US that's driven largely

by long sentences for drug offences. I've
put some links in the doobilydoo for those
who are interested.

Alright, moving on to TFIOS movie stuff, so
quick catch up Hank: I wrote a book called

The Fault in Our Stars; which by the way comes
out in paperback today, that's probably what

I should have made my video about, but whatever,
I wanted to talk about prisons. And GIFs ("guy-fs"),

apparently. Anyway, the movie adaptation of
The Fault in Our Stars comes out June 6th,

but like the hullaballoo and travel leading
into the movie for me like now.

And as part of that hullaballoo, Nat, and
Ansel, and Shailene, and I are going to be

visiting several places around the U.S., doing
I don't really know what yet. But it will

be fun, I'm sure! And Fox is letting people
choose where we go based on Tumblr notes for

various states, so you can go to the link
in the doobilydoo, find your state, like and

reblog it, and that counts as, like, two votes
for your state.

Now, Hank, you would think - and I would think
Fox probably thought - that the votes would

like up according to the population of each
state, but at least so far, no! There are

some very well-organized small states, which
is awesome, because I would like to visit
North Carolina!

Anyway, selfishly, Hank, I want Nerdfighters
to decide where we go, so Nerdfighters, if

you don't mind, go like and reblog your state
on the Tumblr. What's that? Oh, apparently

it's not called "the Tumblr", Hank, it's just
"Tumblr". Nah. I grow old, Hank. I grow old.

I am literally wearing the bottoms of my trousers
rolled.

Hank, I don't even know what this video is
about today. Like, what do you call a video

like this? "TFIOS Prison Movie"? I just had
a great idea for a movie! Alright, Hank, I

have to drop everything and go write my TFIOS
Prison Movie screenplay, I'll see you on Friday.

comments.author: phatkin

comments.text:
Prisons are so corrupt it is crazy. How do we let law get away with this?

- Vast majority of people behind bars are non-violent offenders.

- We pay for their accommodation through tax even though most are perfectly 
safe in the real world and productive for the economy if they're free to 
buy goods and get jobs.

- So many non-violent citizens are locked away whilst those with money or 
political influence get away with the most fucked up things. And police 
brutality too!

- Their prison sentence has stigma enough they struggle to get a job even 
after prison, having to get tax benefits and many turn to stealing. We make 
it worse for them and their criminal mistakes by making it even harder for 
them after a prison sentence than before it, and making crimes like 
stealing even more appealing.

- You are far more likely to be arrested simply by being black...  or 
male...  what the fuck.

- The Halo Effect is a very well documented bias in court ruling. Simply 
put, the less attractive you naturally are (Balding, Acne, skin conditions 
and other things you may not be able to help...)  the much more likely 
you'll be found guilty of a crime regardless of the evidence.

- Prisons profit off the arrest and containment of other people. It's a 
friggin' for-profit business!  Is it just me or is that not fucked up on 
its own?

- Rehabilitation schemes / community service is increasing unpopular in 
favour of just locking them away, punishing them and not addressing their 
root crime / problems.

- A significant percentage of people locked away are eventually found 
not-guilty, and theoretically many who remain guilty may not actually be 
guilty for their crimes. This includes those on Death Row.

- Oh, that's another point...   THE FUCKING DEATH PENALTY STILL EXISTS! 
 ARE WE FUCKING BABARIC!?

FUCKED. UP. WORLD.

.﻿

comments.author: OvercookedPillow

comments.text:
Hi
I have watched a great many of your videos and have found them to be both 
fun and thought provoking. I find “I don’t even know” to be out of 
character with what I have come to expect. By quoting a statistical sound 
bite “Data is overwhelming- a 2013 study by the US sentencing commission 
found that African Americans receive sentences 20% longer that whites for 
similar crimes.”  Without further explanation or commentary you are making 
the unstated hypothesis that judges are raciest. Now I have no problem with 
that conclusion but the way you state it presents the case as neat and 
simple cause and effect – completely out of sync of the complex and nuanced 
video lessons I have come to admire.
 
Thank You
Steven 
DFTB Awesome﻿

comments.text:
Tfios is literally perfect, and it inspired me and helped me through a 
really tough time. Mr. John Green, you are amazing and inspiring and just 
all in all a one-of-a kind man. Please know that I truly admire you, and 
think that your books ( and videos) are magnificently-magnificent.(<<hehe 
idk that kinda reminded me of Gus!) Anyways, I really enjoyed the book, and 
it had helped me to cope with my mom being diagnosed with cancer. I hope to 
be a writer someday too, and you have really inspired me with your writing 
and characters to go after my dreams and live life in the present. We have 
to learn to live, because today is all we have and tomorrow is unknown. 
Your biggest fan, 
~Emma Dove💕 (btw I'm in love with Agustus Waters/Ansel Elgort, I think 
Shailene is honestly gorgeous and inspiring, and issac is a great friend to 
Agustus and is AWESOME!)﻿
